awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Evictions: Causes, Consequences, and Institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
This research studies the mechanisms through which eviction and housing instability affect low-income families. Eviction is a frequent source of housing instability among the urban poor, and recent research suggests that it is a key factor limiting the upward mobility of American families. Yet existing evidence on the consequences of eviction is based on comparisons of evicted tenants to similar non-evicted tenants, making it difficult to isolate eviction as a root cause of urban poverty rather than a symptom of other causes such as job loss or deteriorating health. This research contributes to the existing body of evidence by evaluating the causal effects of eviction on three sets of outcomes: household relocation, financial health, and children's educational outcomes. The investigators use linked administrative data on eviction court cases, outcome data after the court ruling, and a quasi-experimental design. In addition to estimating the causal impact of eviction, this research provides new descriptive evidence on the common pathways into eviction, information on the population facing eviction, and the types of financial stresses that precede an appearance in eviction court.

This research investigates the causes and consequences of residential eviction for low-income American families. The investigators assemble a novel dataset on over 700,000 eviction court cases from Cook County, IL, and link these cases to several administrative datasets, which allows them to measure: (1) household relocation, including neighborhood choice, household composition, and homelessness; (2) financial health, including employment, earnings, public assistance receipt, and access to credit; and (3) children's educational outcomes, including school switching, disenrollment, absenteeism, academic achievement, and behavioral incidents. This research uses a quasi-experimental research design to identify the causal impact of eviction on these outcomes. For identification, the investigators leverage the random assignment of judges to eviction cases, along with variation in leniency across judges. This research uses linked credit data and administrative data to study the population appearing in housing court, the evolution of financial strain in the run-up to eviction, and whether the consequences of eviction differ by the sources of financial distress, contrasting negative shocks from more gradual declines in financial health.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
More than two million eviction court cases are filed in the United States each year. Despite the number of tenants who interact with housing courts and the growing interest from policymakers, the consequences of eviction for households are not well understood.

 

This NSF funded project has produced new evidence on the impact of eviction on tenants’ housing instability, employment and earnings, financial strain, and health. We link eviction court records at the individual level to administrative outcomes including employment and earnings, residential location, homelessness, hospital records, and credit reports. This study is the first to link eviction court records to administrative outcomes data, allowing us to study multiple dimensions of tenants’ lives beginning four years prior to eviction court and continuing up to six years after court.

 

We first show that tenants in eviction court differ substantially from tenants who live in the same neighborhoods. Compared to their neighbors, tenants in housing court have lower earnings, lower employment, less access to credit, and more debt. In addition, both evicted and non-evicted tenants experience striking drops in earnings, employment, and credit scores and rising hospital visits, unpaid bills, and payday loan inquiries in the two years before the case.

 

Next, we provide new causal estimates of the impact of eviction on tenant outcomes using a research design that leverages the random assignment of judges who differ in their propensity to evict. We find that receiving an eviction order has a causal impact on housing instability in the 1-2 years following eviction court, increasing residential mobility, homeless shelter use, and interactions with homelessness services. We find that an eviction order reduces earnings, credit access, and durable goods consumption. The effects of eviction on housing and labor market outcomes are larger for female and Black tenants.

 

As an extension to the completed work, we have ongoing work which studies the impacts of eviction on children’s educational performance and outcomes in Chicago and New York. While still in progress, this work leverages the data construction and linkage funded by the NSF and extends our finished work. Finally, the data collection and linkage completed as part of this project had laid the groundwork for other planned and in-progress projects, such as an analysis of how evictions affect mortality and hospitalization among older renters. 

 

Project outcomes: Intellectual merit

 

  • Publications Resulting from the NSF Award: “Eviction and Poverty in American Cities” (Rob Collinson, John Eric Humphries, Nicholas Mader, Davin Reed, Daniel Tannenbaum, and Winnie van Dijk) Accepted, Quarterly Journal of Economics. (Circulated as NBER Working Paper #30382).

 

  • Manuscripts in Progress Resulting from the NSF Award: “The Effects of Eviction on Children” (Rob Collinson, Deniz Dutz, John Eric Humphries, Nicholas Mader, Daniel Tannenbaum, and Winnie van Dijk) for submission to a peer-reviewed journal.

 

Project outcomes: broader impacts


  • As part of this major data collection and linkage effort, we have trained and supported several undergraduate research assistants and pre-doctoral students who have applied and are attending PhD programs in economics, including at the University of Chicago and Columbia University, with another research assistant applying this year and another next year.

 

  • We have trained and mentored students to assist at all stages of this project, including preparing literature reviews, performing data cleaning, reviewing and writing code for the analysis of datasets, reproducing or validating earlier results, writing sections of the manuscript, and producing tables and figures based on analysis output.

 

  • We have communicated our findings with journalists and reporters from national news outlets to discuss the results of our research before and during the Covid-19 pandemic, to discuss ways in which our research can inform public policy. We have also discussed and shared our work with a number of policy makers, policy advocates, and practitioners.

 

  • We presented the manuscript in several high-profile academic seminar series and conferences to present the results of the research, including the NBER Summer Institute, the American Economics Association Annual Meetings, the Society of Labor Economists Annual Meetings, the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, UC Berkeley, Yale University, UC Los Angeles, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, the University of Kansas, UC Merced, the University of Oregon, and many others.

 

  • We have used the output of this project to construct teaching materials that have been used in teaching econometrics to over 500 undergraduates at Yale, PhD students at Harvard University, and approximately 250 undergraduates at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln.

Last Modified: 11/01/2022
Modified by: John E Humphries

More than two million eviction court cases are filed in the United States each year. Despite the number of tenants who interact with housing courts and the growing interest from policymakers, the consequences of eviction for households are not well understood.

 
This NSF funded project has produced new evidence on the impact of eviction on tenants’ housing instability, employment and earnings, financial strain, and health. We link eviction court records at the individual level to administrative outcomes including employment and earnings, residential location, homelessness, hospital records, and credit reports. This study is the first to link eviction court records to administrative outcomes data, allowing us to study multiple dimensions of tenants’ lives beginning four years prior to eviction court and continuing up to six years after court.

 
We first show that tenants in eviction court differ substantially from tenants who live in the same neighborhoods. Compared to their neighbors, tenants in housing court have lower earnings, lower employment, less access to credit, and more debt. In addition, both evicted and non-evicted tenants experience striking drops in earnings, employment, and credit scores and rising hospital visits, unpaid bills, and payday loan inquiries in the two years before the case.

We find that receiving an eviction order has a causal impact on housing instability in the 1-2 years following eviction court, increasing residential mobility, homeless shelter use, and interactions with homelessness services. As an extension to the completed work, we have ongoing work which studies the impacts of eviction on children’s educational performance and outcomes in Chicago and New York. While still in progress, this work leverages the data construction and linkage funded by the NSF and extends our finished work. Finally, the data collection and linkage completed as part of this project had laid the groundwork for other planned and in-progress projects, such as an analysis of how evictions affect mortality and hospitalization among older renters. 

 
Project outcomes: Intellectual merit
 

Publications Resulting from the NSF Award: "Eviction and Poverty in American Cities" (Rob Collinson, John Eric Humphries, Nicholas Mader, Davin Reed, Daniel Tannenbaum, and Winnie van Dijk) Accepted, Quarterly Journal of Economics. (Circulated as NBER Working Paper #30382).


 

Manuscripts in Progress Resulting from the NSF Award: "The Effects of Eviction on Children" (Rob Collinson, Deniz Dutz, John Eric Humphries, Nicholas Mader, Daniel Tannenbaum, and Winnie van Dijk) for submission to a peer-reviewed journal.


 
Project outcomes: broader impacts



As part of this major data collection and linkage effort, we have trained and supported several undergraduate research assistants and pre-doctoral students who have applied and are attending PhD programs in economics, including at the University of Chicago and Columbia University, with another research assistant applying this year and another next year.


 

We have trained and mentored students to assist at all stages of this project, including preparing literature reviews, performing data cleaning, reviewing and writing code for the analysis of datasets, reproducing or validating earlier results, writing sections of the manuscript, and producing tables and figures based on analysis output.


 

We have communicated our findings with journalists and reporters from national news outlets to discuss the results of our research before and during the Covid-19 pandemic, to discuss ways in which our research can inform public policy. We have also discussed and shared our work with a number of policy makers, policy advocates, and practitioners.


 

We presented the manuscript in several high-profile academic seminar series and conferences to present the results of the research, including the NBER Summer Institute, the American Economics Association Annual Meetings, the Society of Labor Economists Annual Meetings, the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, UC Berkeley, Yale University, UC Los Angeles, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, the University of Kansas, UC Merced, the University of Oregon, and many others.


 

We have used the output of this project to construct teaching materials that have been used in teaching econometrics to over 500 undergraduates at Yale, PhD students at Harvard University, and approximately 250 undergraduates at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln.
